docs.snippet: Parliament ratified a new extradition treaty with the United States, giving both nations a potentially powerful new tool to bring remaining World War II criminals to trial. The treaty replaces one signed in 1923, which falls short of international...
docs.lead_paragraph: Parliament ratified a new extradition treaty with the United States, giving both nations a potentially powerful new tool to bring remaining World War II criminals to trial. The treaty replaces one signed in 1923, which falls short of international legal standards and is limited to extraditing foreigners. The new treaty permits extradition of any accused felon and also allows Lithuania to refuse extradition of accused people who might face the death penalty in the United States. The Simon Wiesenthal Center last year issued a list of 97 Lithuanians suspected of genocide, 37 of whom were said to live in the United States. Michael Wines (NYT)
docs.abstract: Lithuanian Parliament ratifies new extradition treaty with United States, giving both nations powerful new tool to bring World War II criminals to trial (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: A Tool To Pursue War Criminals

docs.snippet: THE late 1990's boom was something like a great party. Not only did the party make people feel good, it made them forget their other troubles.    But even great parties must end. On the morning after, the hangover arrives. Then the partygoers reca...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE late 1990's boom was something like a great party. Not only did the party make people feel good, it made them forget their other troubles. But even great parties must end. On the morning after, the hangover arrives. Then the partygoers recall what was worrying them before the party became so much fun.
docs.abstract: Floyd Norris column questions wisdom of Bush administration's push for creation of international cartel in steel industry resulting from agreements with steel-producing nations to cut production and thus raise prices; graph (M)

docs.snippet: A Korean War veteran who lied about witnessing the killing of refugees by American soldiers in the Korean War pleaded guilty to defrauding the government. The veteran, Edward Lee Daily of Clarksville, falsely claimed he was a wounded prisoner of w...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Korean War veteran who lied about witnessing the killing of refugees by American soldiers in the Korean War pleaded guilty to defrauding the government. The veteran, Edward Lee Daily of Clarksville, falsely claimed he was a wounded prisoner of war to gain government benefits. . He was one of a dozen Army veterans who told The Associated Press in 1999 about the killings at No Gun Ri. He later said he was not there.
docs.abstract: Edward Lee Daily, Korean War veteran who lied about witnessing killing of refugees by American soldiers in Korean War, pleads guilty to defrauding government to gain government benefits (S)

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Guilty Plea On War Claim

docs.snippet: More than 50 combat officers and soldiers in the Israeli Army reserve have said they will refuse to serve in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, setting off heated debate in Israel over the limits of civil disobedience.    The statement, which was publi...
docs.lead_paragraph: More than 50 combat officers and soldiers in the Israeli Army reserve have said they will refuse to serve in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, setting off heated debate in Israel over the limits of civil disobedience. The statement, which was published in the liberal newspaper Haaretz last week as Israelis began their weekend, condemned military actions against the Palestinians during the last 16 months of violence.
docs.abstract: More than 50 combat officers and soldiers in Israeli Army reserve say they will refuse to serve in West Bank and Gaza Strip, setting off heated debate in Israel over limits of civil disobedience; issue statement condemning military actions against Palestinians during past 16 months of violence; say people on both sides of conflict are paying in blood for Israel's occupation of Palestinian territory and its war to protect Jewish settlers in West Bank and Gaza (M)

headline.main: Israeli Group Declares Limit In Making War On Palestinians

docs.snippet: Nelson Mandela, who was criticized in some quarters here for coming out strongly in support of the American-led campaign against terrorism, said today that he may have overstated his backing for the war and that his earlier comments may have unint...
docs.lead_paragraph: Nelson Mandela, who was criticized in some quarters here for coming out strongly in support of the American-led campaign against terrorism, said today that he may have overstated his backing for the war and that his earlier comments may have unintentionally suggested that he was ignoring the conflict's toll on ordinary people. ''Our view may have been one-sided and overstated,'' said Mr. Mandela, a Nobel Peace laureate as well as South African's first post-apartheid president. He added that ''such unreserved support for the war in Afghanistan gives the impression that we are insensitive to and uncaring about the suffering inflicted upon the Afghan people and country.''
docs.abstract: Nelson Mandela, elder statesman of South Africa, says he may have overstated his backing for American-led campaign against terrorism and that his earlier comments may have unintentionally suggested he was ignoring conflict's toll on ordinary people; Mandela was criticized in some quarters in South Africa for coming out strongly for war in Afghanistan; he has been bridge to Muslim communities throughout world; rarely has he been target of sort of anger that followed his remarks on war in Nov, during trip to US; South Africa has influential Muslim minority; Mandela's latest statement seen as concession to critics; in statement, he also questions 'labeling' of Osama bin Laden as terrorist responsible for Sept 11 attacks on New York and Washington before he has been tried and convicted (M)

headline.main: In Statement, Mandela Shifts On All-Out Support for War

docs.snippet: Leaders of the African countries entangled in Congo's civil war met in the Zambian capital, Lusaka, to try to ease the impasse in peace talks that began several weeks ago in South Africa. But while they issued a statement calling on all parties to...
docs.lead_paragraph: Leaders of the African countries entangled in Congo's civil war met in the Zambian capital, Lusaka, to try to ease the impasse in peace talks that began several weeks ago in South Africa. But while they issued a statement calling on all parties to observe a cease-fire agreement no new plan on ending the war emerged. Angola, Namibia and Zimbabwe have provided military support to the government; Rwanda and Uganda have backed the rebels who control much of the eastern part of Congo. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)
docs.abstract: Leaders of African countries entangled in Congo civil war meet in Zambia (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Summit Meeting On Civil War

docs.snippet: To pull the struggling Miss America pageant into the 21st century, Robert M. Renneisen Jr., its chief executive, has proposed some unconventional ideas, like moving the pageant from Atlantic City -- perhaps to an Indian casino in Connecticut -- an...
docs.lead_paragraph: To pull the struggling Miss America pageant into the 21st century, Robert M. Renneisen Jr., its chief executive, has proposed some unconventional ideas, like moving the pageant from Atlantic City -- perhaps to an Indian casino in Connecticut -- and licensing a Miss America slot machine. Mr. Renneisen's proposals have prompted the kind of fiery outcry one might expect after suggesting a face lift to a faded but vain beauty queen.
docs.abstract: Katie Harman, Miss America, professes devotion to job and Miss America Organization, news conference with pageant chief executive Robert M Renneisen Jr, after some disgruntled state pageant administrators circulate letter of complaint from her parents in effort to oust him; state pageant directors oppose changes he seeks to increase profits and attract younger television audience; he defends efforts, interview; photo (M)

headline.main: State Pageants at War With Miss America Organization

docs.snippet: ENEMY WOMEN  By Paulette Jiles  321 pages. William Morrow. $24.95.      There are Civil War stories of suffering and nobility, of romances and families destroyed by the fateful ravages of battle. Paulette Jiles's ''Enemy Women'' isn't so far afiel...
docs.lead_paragraph: ENEMY WOMEN By Paulette Jiles 321 pages. William Morrow. $24.95. There are Civil War stories of suffering and nobility, of romances and families destroyed by the fateful ravages of battle. Paulette Jiles's ''Enemy Women'' isn't so far afield of those, yet it is another kind of novel entirely. This is a book with backbone, written with tough, haunting eloquence by an author determined to capture the immediacy of her heroine's wartime odyssey. And Ms. Jiles, in her debut novel, has brought spellbinding intensity to the process of leading readers backward through time.
docs.abstract: Janet Maslin reviews book Enemy Women by Paulette Jiles; photo (M)

headline.main: Civil War Odyssey of a Heroine Wily and Brave

docs.snippet: Anne Poor, an American artist who painted combat scenes in World War II and later concentrated on dreamlike landscapes, died in Nyack, N.Y., on Jan. 12. She was 84 and lived in Haverstraw, N.Y.    A native of New York City, Ms. Poor studied at the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Anne Poor, an American artist who painted combat scenes in World War II and later concentrated on dreamlike landscapes, died in Nyack, N.Y., on Jan. 12. She was 84 and lived in Haverstraw, N.Y. A native of New York City, Ms. Poor studied at the Art Students League while in high school. In the 1930's she helped her stepfather, the artist Henry Varnum Poor, paint murals for the United States Justice Department and the Department of the Interior in Washington. While in the Women's Army Corps in 1943 she gained attention for her depictions of military life, including air evacuation of the wounded in the Pacific. The paintings were exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and the National Gallery of Art in Washington.
docs.abstract: Anne Poor, American artist who painted combat scenes in World War II, dies at age 84 (M)

headline.main: Anne Poor, 84, Painter of War And Landscape

docs.snippet: The military campaign in Afghanistan was a striking success for a new style of warfare, in which American commandos took center stage and played a vital role in organizing the Afghan resistance and directing punishing airstrikes.     The novel str...
docs.lead_paragraph: The military campaign in Afghanistan was a striking success for a new style of warfare, in which American commandos took center stage and played a vital role in organizing the Afghan resistance and directing punishing airstrikes. The novel strategy enabled the United States to topple the Taliban, install a friendly government and ensure that Al Qaeda could no longer use Afghanistan as a base for terrorism.
docs.abstract: Article on US military campaign in Afghanistan as striking success for new style of warfare, in which American commandos took center stage, playing vital role in organizing Afghan resistance and directing punishing airstrikes; novel strategy toppled Taliban, installed friendly government and ensured that Al Qaeda cannot use Afghanistan as base for terrorism, achieving these ends with small number of American ground troops and little political backlash in Muslim world; drawback is that proxy forces may have allowed top Taliban and Qaeda leaders to escape; US intelligence finds low-level militia may have smuggled Arab fighters out of Tora Bora area for up to $5,000 a head; strategy in most unorthodox war reviewed; chronology of US actions since Sept 11 terrorist attacks; maps (L)

headline.main: Gains and Limits in New Low-Risk War
